lesson.name: Lesson 1.10 Connecting Equations to Graphs, Part 1

page.title: 1.10.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will learn how the parameters and variables relate to features of the graphs of two-variable linear equations. In addition, you will think about how different forms of two-variable equations affect the information we could gain about the relationships between the quantities and about the graphs.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Describe the connections between an equation of the form \( ax+by=c \), the features of its graph, and the rate of change in the situation.
  • Graph linear equations of the form \( ax+by=c \).
  • Demonstrate that rewriting the equation for a line in different forms can make it easier to find certain kinds of information about the relationship and about the graph.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals

  • 1.10.1: Interpreting Equations in Context 
  • 1.10.2: Graphing Equations in Context
  • 1.10.2: Self Check 
  • 1.10.3: Writing and Graphing Equations in Standard Form
  • 1.10.3: Self Check
  • 1.10.4: Matching Equations and Graphs

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 1.10.5: Practice
  • 1.10.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 1.10.1: Interpreting Equations in Context
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Jada has $20 to spend on games and rides at a carnival. Games cost $1 each and rides are $2 each.

  1. Which equation represents the relationship between the number of games, \( x \), and the number of rides, \( y \), that Jada could do if she spends all her money?

    1. \( x + y = 20 \)
    2. \( 2x + y = 20 \)
    3. \( x + 2y = 20 \)
  1. Explain what each of the other two equations could mean in this situation.

Enter your answers here:

Compare your answers to these sample responses:

  1. Sample Responses:
    1. Jada spends $20 on games and rides, which are $1 each.
    2. The combined number of games and rides that Jada enjoys is 20.
  2. Sample Response: Jada spends $20 on games and rides, where games are $2 each and rides are $1 each.

page.title: 1.10.2: Graphing Equations in Context
page.contents:
Activity

Here are three equations. Each represents the relationship between the number of games, \(x\), the number of rides, \(y\), and the dollar amount a student is spending on games and rides at a different amusement park.

Equation 1: \( x + y = 20 \)

Equation 2: \( 2.50x + y = 15 \)

Equation 3: \( x + 4y = 28 \)

Your teacher will assign to you (or ask you to choose) 1–2 equations. For each assigned (or chosen) equation, answer the questions.

First equation: \( \underline{\hspace{50mm}} \)

  1. What’s the number of rides the student could get on if they don’t play any games? On the coordinate plane, mark the point that represents this situation and label the point with its coordinates.
Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:

20 rides, plot point (0, 20)

  1. What’s the number of games the student could play if they don’t get on any rides? On the coordinate plane, mark the point that represents this situation and label the point with its coordinates.
Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:

20 games, plot point (20, 0)


  1. Draw a line to connect the two points you’ve drawn.

  1. Complete the sentences: “If the student played no games, they can get on \( \underline{\hspace{.75in}} \) rides. For every additional game that the student plays, \( x \), the possible number of rides, \( y \), \( \underline{\hspace{1.5in}} \) (increases or decreases) by \( \underline{\hspace{.75in}} \).”
Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:
  1. 20
  2. Decreases
  3. 1

  1. What is the slope of your graph? Where does the graph intersect the vertical axis?
Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:

-1; (0,20)

  1. Rearrange the equation to solve for \( y \).
Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:

\(y = -x+20\) or \(y = 20-x\)

  1. What connections, if any, do you notice between your new equation and the graph?
Enter your answers here:
Compare your answers:

The new equation shows where the graph intersects the y-axis at 20 and the slope of the graph, -1.

Watch the following video to see how this is done.

  

Second equation: \( 2.50x+y=15 \)

  1. What’s the number of rides the student could get on if they don’t play any games? On the coordinate plane, mark the point that represents this situation and label the point with its coordinates.

Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:

15 rides, plot point (0, 15)

  1. What’s the number of games the student could play if they don’t get on any rides? On the coordinate plane, mark the point that represents this situation and label the point with its coordinates.

Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:

6 games, plot point (6, 0)

  1. Draw a line to connect the two points you’ve drawn.
  2. Complete the sentences: “If the student played no games, they can get on \( \underline{\hspace{.75in}} \) rides. For every additional game that a student plays, \( x \), the possible number of rides, \( y \), \( \underline{\hspace{1.5in}} \) (increases or decreases) by \( \underline{\hspace{.75in}} \).”

Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:
  1. 15
  2. Decreases
  3. 2.5

  1. What is the slope of your graph? Where does the graph intersect the vertical axis?
Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:

-2.5; (0,15)

  1. Rearrange the equation to solve for \( y \).
Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:

\(y = -2.5x+15\) or \(y = 15-2.5x\)

  1. What connections, if any, do you notice between your new equation and the graph?
Enter your answers here:
Compare your answers:

The new equation shows where the graph intersects the y-axis at 15. So, if the student plays 0 games, they have the money to go on 15 rides. Since the slope of the graph is -2.5, for every 2.5 fewer rides they go on, they can play 1 game.

Third equation: \(x+4y=28 \)

  1. What’s the number of rides the student could get on if they don’t play any games? On the coordinate plane, mark the point that represents this situation and label the point with its coordinates.

Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:

15 rides, plot point (0, 7)

  1. What’s the number of games the student could play if they don’t get on any rides? On the coordinate plane, mark the point that represents this situation and label the point with its coordinates.

Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:

28 games, plot point (28, 0)

  1. Draw a line to connect the two points you’ve drawn.
  2. Complete the sentences: “If the student played no games, they can get on \( \underline{\hspace{.75in}} \) rides. For every additional game that a student plays, \( x \), the possible number of rides, \( y \), \( \underline{\hspace{1.5in}} \) (increases or decreases) by \( \underline{\hspace{.75in}} \).”

Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:
  1. 7
  2. Decreases
  3. \(\frac{1}{4}\)

  1. What is the slope of your graph? Where does the graph intersect the vertical axis?

Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:

\(\frac{1}{4}\);(0, 7)

  1. Rearrange the equation to solve for \( y \).

Enter your answers here:
Check your answers:

\(y = 7 - \frac{1}{4}x\) or \(y = -\frac{1}{4}x + 7\)

  1. What connections, if any, do you notice between your new equation and the graph?

Enter your answers here:
Compare your answers:

Sample response: The new equation shows where the graph intersects the y-axis (at 7) and the slope of the graph \((-\frac{1}{4})\).

page.title: 1.10.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following equations correctly solved \( 2x+4y=8 \) for \( y \)?

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: To solve for y, first subtract \( 2x \)  from both sides then divide both sides by 4. Finally, simplify any fractions.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Make sure you solve for \( y \) , not \( x \) . The answer is \( y=\frac{-1}{2}x+2 \).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Make sure to subtract \( 2x \)  from both sides of the equation when solving for \( y \) . The answer is \( y=\frac{-1}{2}x+2 \).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Make sure to divide all of the terms by 4. The answer is \( y=\frac{-1}{2}x+2 \).

page.title: 1.10.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Find the Slop of a Line

When you graph linear equations, you may notice that some lines tilt up as they go from left to right and some lines tilt down. Some lines are very steep and some lines are flatter.

In mathematics, the measure of the steepness of a line is called the of slope the line.

The concept of slope has many applications in the real world. In construction the pitch of a roof, the slant of the plumbing pipes, and the steepness of the stairs are all applications of slope. As you ski or jog down a hill, you definitely experience a slope.

We can assign a numerical value to the slope of a line by finding the ratio of the rise and run. The rise is the amount the vertical distance changes while the run measures the horizontal change, as shown in this illustration. Slope is a rate of change.

Slope of a Line

The slope of a line is \( m = \frac{rise}{run} \). The rise measures the vertical change and the run measures the horizontal change.

To find the slope of a line, we locate two points on the line whose coordinates are integers. Then we sketch a right triangle where the two points are vertices and one side is horizontal and one side is vertical.

To find the slope of the line, we measure the distance along the vertical and horizontal sides of the triangle. The vertical distance is called the rise and the horizontal distance is called the run.

How To

Find the slope of a line from its graph using \( m = \frac{rise}{run} \)

  1. Step 1. Locate two points on the line whose coordinates are integers.
  2. Step 2. Starting with one point, sketch a right triangle, going from the first point to the second point.
  3. Step 3. Count the rise and the run on the legs of the triangle.
  4. Step 4. Take the ratio of rise to run to find the slope: \( m = \frac{rise}{run} \)
Example
Find the slope of the line shown.

Solution:


Locate two points on the graph whose coordinates are integers. 

(0, 5) and (3, 3)
Starting at (0,5), sketch a right triangle to (3,3) as shown in this graph.

Count the rise(how many spaces up or down)— since it goes down, it is negative.

The rise is -2.

Count the run (how many spaces to the right or left).

The run is 3.

Use the slope formula.

\( m = \frac{rise}{run} \)

Substitute the values of the rise and run.

\( m = \frac{-2}{3} \)

Simplify.

\( m = -\frac{2}{3} \)

So \( y \) decreases by 2 units as \( x \) increases by 3 units.

How do we find the slope of horizontal and vertical lines? To find the slope of the horizontal line, \( y = 4 \), we could graph the line, find two points on it, and count the rise and the run. Let’s see what happens when we do this, as shown in the graph below.

What is the rise?
 The rise is 0.
What is the run?
 The run is 3.
What is the slope?
 \( m = \frac{rise}{run} \)

\( m = \frac{0}{3} \)

\( m = 0 \)

The slope of the horizontal line \( y = 4 \) is 0.

Let's also consider a vertical line, the line \( x = 3 \), as shown in the graph below.


What is the rise?
 The rise is 2.
What is the run?
 The run is 0.
What is the slope?
 \( m = \frac{rise}{run} \)

\( m = \frac{2}{0} \)

The slope is undefined since division by zero is undefined. So we say that the slope of the vertical line is undefined.

All horizontal lines have slope 0. When the y-coordinates are the same, the rise is 0.

The slope of any vertical line is undefined. When the x-coordinates of a line are all the same, the run is 0.


Quick Guide to the Slopes of Lines


Sometimes we’ll need to find the slope of a line between two points when we don’t have a graph to count out the rise and the run. We could plot the points on grid paper, then count out the rise and the run, but as we’ll see, there is a way to find the slope without graphing. Before we get to it, we need to introduce some algebraic notation.
 
We have seen that an ordered pair (x,y) gives the coordinates of a point. But when we work with slopes, we use two points. How can the same symbol (x,y) be used to represent two different points? Mathematicians use subscripts to distinguish the points.
 
We will use (x1, y1) to identify the first point and (x2, y2) to identify the second point.

Let’s see how the rise and run relate to the coordinates of the two points by taking another look at the slope of the line between the points (2,3)and (7,6), as shown in this graph.


Since we have two points, we will use subscript notation.
 \( \binom {x_1, y_1} {2, 3} \) \( \binom {x_2, y_2} {7, 6} \)

\( m = \frac{rise}{run} \)
On the graph, we counted the rise of 3 and the run of 5.
 \( m = \frac{3}{5} \)
Notice that the rise of 3 can be found by subtracting the \( y \)-coordinates, 6 and 3, and the run of 5 can be found by subtracting the \( x \)-coordinates 7 and 2.
We rewrite the rise and run by putting in the coordinates.
 \( m = \frac{6-3}{7-2} \)
But 6 is \( y \)2, the \( y \)-coordinate of the second point and 3 is \( y \)1, the \( y \)-coordinate of the first point. So we can rewrite the slope using subscript notation.
 \( m = \frac{y_2-y_1}{7-2} \)
Also, 7 is the \( x \)-coordinate of the second point and 2 is the \( x \)-coordinate of the first point. So again, we rewrite the slop using subscript notation.
 \( m = \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \)

We've shown that \( m = \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \) is really another version of \( m = \frac{rise}{run} \). We can use this formula to find the slope of a line when we have two points on the line.

Slope of a Line Between Two Points
The slope of the line between two points (\( x_1, y_1 )\) and (\(x_2, y_2\))  is: 
\( m = \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \)

Example 2:

Use the slope formula to find the slope of the line through the points (−2,−3) and (-7, 4).

We'll call (-2, -3) point #1 and (-7, 4) point #2.
 \( \binom {x_1, y_1} {-2, -3} \) \( \binom {x_2, y_2} {-7, 4} \)
Use the slope formula.
 \( m = \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \)
Substitute the values.
\( y \) of the second point minus \( y \) of the first point
\( x \) of the second point minus \( x \) of the first point
 \( m = \frac{4-(-3)1}{-7(-2)} \)
Simplify.
 \( m = \frac{7}{-5} \)
\( m = -\frac{7}{5} \)

\( m = \frac{y_2-y1}{7-2} \)
Let's verify this slope on the graph shown.
 \( m = \frac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \)

Try It: Find the Slope of a Line

Find the slope of the line graph below.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to find the slope of a line from the graph.

Locate two points on the graph whose coordinates are integers.

(0, -5) (4, 1)
Starting at (0,-5), sketch a right triangle to (4,1) as shown in this graph.

Count the rise (how many spaces up or down)—since it goes up, it is positive.

The rise is -6.

Count the run (how many spaces to the right or left).

The run is 4.

Use the slope formula.

Substitute the values of the rise and run.

m = 64

Simplify.

m =32

So y increases by 3 units as x increases by 2 units.


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking.
Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.10.3: Writing and Graphing Equations in Standard Form
page.contents:
Activity

Andre’s coin jar contains 85 cents. There are no quarters or pennies in the jar, so the jar has all nickels, all dimes, or some of each.

  1. Write an equation that relates the number of nickels, \( n \), the number of dimes, \( d \), and the amount of money, in cents, in the coin jar.

\(5n+10d=85\), where n is the number of nickels and d is the number of dimes.

  1. Graph your equation on the coordinate plane. Be sure to label the axes.


  1. How many nickels are in the jar if there are no dimes?

17 nickels

  1. How many dimes are in the jar if there are no nickels?

It's not possible for the coin jar to have no nickels if the amount of money in it is 85 cents.

Extending Your Thinking

What are all the different ways the coin jar could have 85 cents if it could also contain quarters?

Enter your answer here:
Check your answer: Listed as nickels, dimes, quarters: (17,0,0), (15,1,0), (13,2,0), (12,0,1), (11,3,0), (10,1,1), (9,4,0), (8,2,1), (7,0,2), (7,5,0), (6,3,1), (5,1,2),(5,6,0), (4,4,1), (3,2,2), (2,0,3), (3,7,0), (2,5,1), (1,3,2), (0,1,3), (1,8,0), (0,6,1)

page.title: 1.10.4: Matching Equations and Graphs
page.contents:
Activity

Kiran is spending $12 on games and rides at another carnival, where a game costs $0.25 and a ride costs $1.

  1. Write an equation to represent the relationship between the dollar amount Kiran is spending and the number of games, \( x \), and the number of rides, \( y \), he could do.

Enter your answer here:
\(0.25x + y = 12\)

  1. Which graph represents the relationship between the quantities in this situation?

    A

    B

    C


Choose the correct graph.
Graph C (for \(y = 12 - 14x\))

  1. Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:
Compare your responses to these sample explanations:
  • If Kiran plays 0 games, he could get on 12 rides. If he gets on 0 rides, he could play 48 games. Both the points (0,12) and (48,0) are on the line in Graph C.
  • Rearranging the equation into slope-intercept form gives \(y=12−\frac{1}{4}x\), so the graph has a slope of \(-\frac{1}{4}\) and intersects the y-axis at 12, which matches Graph C.

page.title: 1.10.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Describe the connections between an equation of the form ax+by=c , the features of its graph, and the rate of change in the situation.
  • Graph a linear equation of the form ax+by=c .
  • Demonstrate that rewriting the equation for a line in different forms can make it easier to find certain kinds of information about the relationship and about the graph.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 1.10.1 Interpreting Equations in Context 
    • In this activity, you explained how equations matched given situations.
  • 1.10.2  Graphing Equations in Context
    • In this activity, you used a graph of an equation to look at possible solutions to the situation.
  • 1.10.2 Self Check 
  • 1.10.3 Writing and Graphing Equations in Standard Form
    • In this activity, you explored writing and graphing equations in standard form. You then worked on solving the equations for y and recognized where the slope and y-intercept are located in the new equations.
  • 1.10.3 Self Check 
  • 1.10.4 Matching Equations and Graphs
    • In this activity, you wrote an equation to represent the number of rides and games that Kiran could do and matched the graph to this equation given the amount he could spend.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 1.10.5: Practice
  • 1.11.6: Lesson Summary

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.

page.title: 1.10.3: Self Check
page.contents: A coin jar contains 75 cents and only contains quarters and nickels. Write an equation that relates the number of quarters, \( q \), the number of nickels, \( n \), and the amount of money, in cents, in the coin jar.

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: Each quarter is worth 25 cents or 0.25 of a dollar and each nickel is worth 5 cents or 0.05 of a dollar. The total is 75 cents or 0.75. Then multiply each decimal on both sides by 100.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Write the value of the quarters and nickels as cents. The answer is \( 25q + 5n =75 \),
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The sum of the amount of nickels and quarters will equal 75 cents, not the difference. The answer is \( 25q + 5n =75 \),
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The sum of the amount of nickels and quarters will equal 75 cents, not the difference. The answer is \( 25q + 5n =75 \),

page.title: 1.10.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For #1-4 Use the problem and graph below: Andre bought a new bag of cat food. The next day, he opened it to feed his cat. The graph shows how many ounces were left in the bag on the days after it was bought.



1. How many ounces of food were in the bag 12 days after Andre bought it? Enter only integers.

Correct! The answer is 36.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.10.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 36. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2. How many days did it take for the bag to contain 16 ounces of food? Enter only integers.

Correct! The answer is 24.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.10.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 24. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3. How much did the bag weigh before it was opened? Enter only integers.

Correct! The answer is 56.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.10.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 56. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4. Approximately many days did it take for the bag to be empty? Enter only integers.

Correct! The answer is 33.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.10.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 33. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For #5-7, use the problem and graph below:
A group of hikers is progressing steadily along an uphill trail. The graph shows their elevation (or height above sea level), in feet, at each distance from the start of the trail, in miles.



5. What is the slope of the graph? Enter only integers.

Correct! The answer is 250.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.10.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is m = 250

6. What does the slope tell us about this situation?

Correct! The answer is the change in elevation as the hikers hike more miles.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.10.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is the change in elevation as the hikers hike more miles.  You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


7. Choose the equation that represents the relationship between the hikers' distance from the start of the trail, x, and their elevation, y.

Correct! \(y=250x+500\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.10.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is y=250x+500.  You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


8. A kindergarten teacher bought $21 worth of stickers and cardstock for his class. The stickers cost $1.50 a sheet and the cardstock cost $3.50 per pack. The equation 1.5s + 3.5c =21 represents the relationship between sheets of stickers, s, packs of cardstocks, c, and the dollar amount a kindergarten teacher spent on these supplies.

Correct! The answer is 0 sheets of stickers and 6 packs of cardstock were bought.

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.10.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 0 sheets of stickers and 6 packs of cardstock were bought. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 1.10.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Standard Form of Linear Equation

A linear equation is in standard form when it is written A x + B y = C .

Most people prefer to have A, B, and C be integers and A ≥ 0 A ≥ 0 when writing a linear equation in standard form, although it is not strictly necessary.

Linear equations have infinitely many solutions. For every number that is substituted for x there is a corresponding y value. This pair of values is a solution to the linear equation and is represented by the ordered pair ( x , y ) . ( x , y ) . When we substitute these values of x and y into the equation, the result is a true statement, because the value on the left side is equal to the value on the right side.

Solution of a Linear Equation in Two Variables

A x + B y = C .

An ordered pair ( x , y ) ( x , y ) is a solution of the linear equation A x + B y = C , A x + B y = C , if the equation is a true statement when the x- and y-values of the ordered pair are substituted into the equation.

Linear equations have infinitely many solutions. We can plot these solutions in the rectangular coordinate system. The points will line up perfectly in a straight line. We connect the points with a straight line to get the graph of the equation. We put arrows on the ends of each side of the line to indicate that the line continues in both directions.

A graph is a visual representation of all the solutions of the equation. It is an example of the saying, “A picture is worth a thousand words.” The line shows you all the solutions to that equation. Every point on the line is a solution of the equation. And, every solution of this equation is on this line. This line is called the graph of the equation. Points not on the line are not solutions!

When a linear equation in standard form is solved for y, it is then easy to pick out the slope of the line and where the graph of the line crosses the y-axis.

Example: Solve \( 3x - 9y = 15 \)

Original Equation
 \( 9x - 3y = 15 \)
Subtract 9x from both sides. \( 9x - 9x - 3y = 15 - 9x \)
Simplify. \( -3y = 15 - 9x \)
Divide both sides by -3. \( \frac{-3y}{3} = \frac{15-9x}{3} \)
Simplify to solve for y. \( y = -3x + 5 \)

In the new equation, \( y = -3x + 5 \), the slope is -3 and the graph of the line would cross the y-axis at 5.

Try It: Understanding Standard Form

Solve \( 6x + 2y =14 \) for \( y \).

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Original Equation
 \( 6x + 2y =14 \)
Subtract 9x from both sides. \( 6x - 6x+ 2y =14 - 6x \)
Simplify. \( 2y = -6x +14 \)
Divide both sides by -3. \( \frac{2y}{2} = \frac{-6x+14}{2} \)
Simplify to solve for y. \( y = -3x + 7 \)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking.
Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I'd like to retry the self check.
I'm ready for the next activty.
